              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-137280-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>In this article, we explain our process of detecting domain name service (DNS) hijacking and provide some notable examples of this detection from the first half of 2024. DNS hijacking allows cybercriminals to modify DNS records of domain names and redirect users to malicious servers.</p>
<p>Threat actors compromise domains for a variety of different types of attacks, including meddler in the middle (MitM) attacks, drive-by downloads, phishing and scams. Hijackers use a victim domain's reputation to direct victims into malicious campaigns, independent of the expectations of its original visitors. For example, to hijack domains criminals can steal domain owners' credentials at registrars or DNS service providers or alternatively infiltrate these services.</p>
<p>To detect DNS hijacking, we process an average of 167 million new DNS records every day. After initial preprocessing, we take the remaining records that are candidates for detection as DNS hijacking, and we extract 74 features from over 169 terabytes of <a href="https://help.passivetotal.org/passive_dns.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">passive DNS (pDNS)</a> and geolocation data. We then use a machine learning model to predict whether or not these candidate records are truly the result of DNS hijacking.</p>
<p>Between March and September 2024, our detection pipeline processed over 29 billion new records and identified 6,729 as hijacking, with an average daily detection of 38 records. Recently, we deployed a new version of our model that can detect DNS hijacking in our customers' traffic in around 10 minutes.</p>
<p>This article provides some notable examples of DNS hijacking that our pipeline has detected over this period. Examples include:</p>
<ul>
<li>The DNS hijacking of a Hungarian political party's domain name</li>
<li>The defacement of a large utility company and internet service provider (ISP)</li>
<li>Using the domains of a university and research center to host illicit gambling</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/ngfw" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a> customers receive protection from DNS hijacking via our automated classifier in the Palo Alto Networks <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> subscription service.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xpanse" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Xpanse</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xsiam" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XSIAM</a> can help customers detect and respond to potential subdomain hijacking risks by identifying susceptible CNAME DNS records on customer-attributed domains.</p>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cybercrime" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Cybercrime</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/dns-hijacking/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DNS Hijacking</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-137280-_wven14kmgum2"></a>Background</h2>
<p>DNS hijacking is a pervasive threat that can have catastrophic consequences for domain owners and their customers. An incident on Oct. 22, 2016, is a stark example of this. Cybercriminals seized control of the entire online operation of a major Brazilian bank with over 5 million customers and 500 branches worldwide, as reported by <a href="https://www.darkreading.com/cyberattacks-data-breaches/cybercriminals-seized-control-of-brazilian-bank-for-5-hours" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Kaspersky Lab</a>.</p>
<p>The attackers gained control of online banking, mobile, point-of-sale, ATM and investment transactions. During the 5-hour attack, the criminals collected electronic transactions, redirected users to phishing sites to steal their login credentials, and attacked users with malware.</p>
<p>When the malware successfully infected customer's machines, it first disabled antimalware software to avoid detection. It then harvested various credentials and targeted other banks the customer might have used.</p>
<p>The attackers gained control of the bank's online assets by compromising the bank's <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNS_hosting_service" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DNS service provider</a>. While the criminal group's method of compromising the DNS service provider is unclear, the attackers were able to control 36 domains belonging to the bank.</p>
<p>The attackers also abused Let's Encrypt as a free and legitimate certificate authority, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_key_certificate" target="_blank" rel="noopener">establishing certificates</a> to make communication with these domains and subsequent malicious servers look legitimate. In summary, DNS hijacking landed a major bank's entire operation in criminal hands.</p>
<p>Threat actors often abuse, take advantage of or subvert legitimate products for malicious purposes. This does not imply that the legitimate product itself is flawed or malicious.</p>
<h3><a id="post-137280-_jtsgulia0tjg"></a>DNS Hijacking in Practice</h3>
<p>Threat actors can hijack DNS records using different methods. An attacker can take over the domain owner's account at a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_name_registrar" target="_blank" rel="noopener">domain registrar</a> or a DNS service provider or infiltrate the registrar/DNS service provider.</p>
<p>For example, attackers can use phishing, password guessing or breach another site to take over accounts. In such scenarios, mitigation techniques such as Domain Name System Security Extensions (DNSSEC) or encrypting DNS queries and responses (e.g., DNS over HTTPS and DNS over TLS) are insufficient to prevent attackers from hijacking the records.</p>
<p>Alternatively, attackers can hijack DNS records via <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cache_poisoning" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DNS cache poisoning</a> or other attacks manipulating DNS responses, such as MitM attacks intercepting communication and modifying the DNS queries on the fly. Cybercriminals hijack DNS records and change the resolution of domains to redirect requests for a domain to a destination they control. DNS hijacking is typically a precursor to other attacks, such as scams or drive-by-downloads.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137280-_obdx0umt62cz"></a>Automatic Detection of DNS Hijacking</h2>
<p>Automatically detecting DNS hijacking is an extreme needle in a haystack challenge. While there are hundreds of billions of DNS records, only a few dozen of them are known cases of DNS hijacking. Figure 1 provides a high-level overview of our machine learning-based detection pipeline consisting of four main steps: preprocessing, feature extraction, machine learning prediction and post-processing.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137284" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137284" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137284 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-715320-137280-1.png" alt="Diagram illustrating a process for DNS hijacking detection. The workflow includes steps like 'New DNS Record', 'Preprocessing', 'Candidate DNS Hijacking Record', and more. Each step is connected through arrows to show the flow from one process to the next." width="900" height="382" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-715320-137280-1.png 1299w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-715320-137280-1-786x333.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-715320-137280-1-768x326.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137284" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Overview of DNS hijacking detection pipeline.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The pipeline relies mainly on two datasets: pDNS and geolocation data. PDNS is a collection of hundreds of terabytes of historical DNS queries and responses from our customers as well as various global vantage points. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_geolocation" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Geolocation data</a> maps IP addresses to their geographical location (e.g., country), ISP and Autonomous System Number (ASN).</p>
<p>The first step in our automatic detection of DNS hijacking is preprocessing, which takes new, never-before-seen DNS records as input. DNS hijackers need to create new DNS records to redirect users to their malicious servers, making new records a good starting point.</p>
<p>Preprocessing removes invalid records and records of new domain names. Never-before-seen hostnames are removed as we lack sufficient historical information about them to reliably decide if DNS hijacking were to occur.</p>
<p>We have a separate <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/domain-shadowing/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">detector for domain shadowing</a>, which is a special case of DNS hijacking where attackers stealthily create new malicious subdomains under compromised domain names. We also remove records that we observe in the history of the registered/root domain portion (e.g., google.co.uk in the case of www.google.co.uk) of the domain name. We consider the output of this preprocessing as our list of candidate DNS hijacking records.</p>
<p>In the second step, our pipeline extracts 74 features about these candidate DNS records using pDNS and geolocation data. Some features compare the historical usage of the new IP address to the old IP address of the domain name in the new record. For example, we compare the number of domains for which an IP address is a new IP address.</p>
<p>Other features compare the geolocation of the IP address in the new record to the historical IP addresses of the domain name. For example, we compare whether the IP address in the new record has a geolocation never seen before for the domain name.</p>
<p>The detector also considers features that describe the pDNS history of the root domain (e.g., how many IP addresses it has resolved to and in how many countries). Once the detector computes a feature vector for a candidate DNS hijacking record, our pipeline sends it to a pre-trained machine learning model.</p>
<p>Third, our machine learning model provides a probability score indicating the likelihood that the candidate DNS hijacking record is really DNS hijacking. We trained a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_forest" target="_blank" rel="noopener">random forest</a> classifier using DNS hijacking records collected from various reports, and records from our pDNS dataset as our benign dataset.</p>
<p>Our benign dataset might contain a small number of DNS hijacking records, but our training algorithm can tolerate this amount of imperfection in our labeled data. The classifier's outputs are the predicted DNS hijacking records.</p>
<p>In the fourth and final step, we further process the predicted DNS hijacking records to decide if they are truly hijacking. While pDNS allows us to observe and process hundreds of millions of new records, it only provides a limited view about these new records.</p>
<p>To address this issue, we collect additional information about the predicted DNS hijacking records that would have been too expensive at an earlier step. First, we look at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WHOIS" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WHOIS</a> data of the domain name in the records. WHOIS provides domain registration data and can tell us if a domain was recently reregistered, eliminating potential false positives.</p>
<p>We also conduct active crawls for the domain name's website using the IP address found in the new record as well as using IP addresses the domain previously resolved to, according to pDNS. If the different web crawls provide identical content or HTTPS certificates, then we don't consider the predicted DNS hijacking record a true DNS hijacking record. We use the final output of our pipeline to block DNS hijacking records for our customers.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137280-_50343o6a6han"></a>Detection Results</h2>
<p>Between March 27, 2024, and September 21, 2024, our pipeline has processed over 29 billion new records. It has also selected more than 583 million candidate DNS hijacking records to process further in our machine learning pipeline. After prediction and post-filtering, our pipeline identified 6,729 records as DNS hijacking.</p>
<p>Figure 2 shows that our machine learning pipeline classifies around 3.3 million candidate DNS hijacking records daily (blue line). After post-filtering, we are left with an average of 38 DNS hijacking records a day (red line).</p>
<figure id="attachment_137286" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137286" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137286 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/chart.png" alt="Line graph depicting the number of candidate records and hijacking records over time from April to September 2024. The candidate records line, shown in blue, ranges between 0 and 500,000, while the hijacking records line, shown in red, fluctuates between 0 and 150." width="700" height="548" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/chart.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/chart-562x440.png 562w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/chart-894x700.png 894w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/chart-768x601.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/chart-1536x1202.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137286" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Daily counts of candidates and predicted DNS hijacking records.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-137280-_pfjazjttxobe"></a>DNS Hijacking in the Wild</h2>
<h3><a id="post-137280-_6b0mla338l4w"></a><strong>DNS Hijacking of Two Companies by Same Group</strong></h3>
<p>On May 8, we detected two domains of one of the largest utility management companies in the U.S. pointing to a new IP address at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">176.9.24[.]28</span>. The FTP service of the website was particularly suspicious, because it had been previously hosted on a different IP address since 2014, as shown in Figure 3.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137288" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137288" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137288 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-722817-137280-3.png" alt="Internet record showing an IP address hijack. The IP address is from Falkenstein, Sachsen, Germany, hosted by Hetzner Online GmbH, with details of geolocation, ISP data, and timestamps for last and first seen dates highlighted." width="900" height="312" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-722817-137280-3.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-722817-137280-3-786x272.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-722817-137280-3-1920x666.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-722817-137280-3-768x266.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-722817-137280-3-1536x533.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137288" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. The detected hijacked record for the FTP service. This record was also detected as hijacking for the main domain.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Apart from the new IP address, there were no other IP addresses associated with this service in the pDNS records. When we examined the screenshot of the FTP service captured by our crawler that’s shown in Figure 4, we noticed that the hijacked IP address hosted a defaced page by a group called Garuda Security.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137290" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137290" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137290 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-726376-137280-4.png" alt="Image of a black background featuring the emblem of the Garuda Security Official, a two-headed eagle in gold. Text overlay includes a hack notification by 'SukaJanda01' discussing cybersecurity vulnerabilities and makes references to Saudi Arabia, UAE, and Israel." width="900" height="689" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-726376-137280-4.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-726376-137280-4-575x440.png 575w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-726376-137280-4-915x700.png 915w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-726376-137280-4-768x588.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-726376-137280-4-1536x1175.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137290" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. The screenshot of the defaced FTP service captured by our crawler.</figcaption></figure>
<p>We further investigated other DNS records associated with the main website and found that hours before the IP address changed, its nameservers (i.e., NS records) were hijacked to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns1[.]csit-host[.]com</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns2[.]csit-host[.]com</span>. Both of the nameservers resolved to the same hijacked IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">176.9.24[.]28</span>.</p>
<p>On May 25, we detected a similar DNS hijacking incident on one of the largest ISPs. Its A record was hijacked to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">176.9.24[.]28</span>, the same IP address used in the DNS hijacking attack against the utility management company, shown in Figure 5.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137292" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137292" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137292 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-731464-137280-5.png" alt="Table labeled 'Hijacked Record' displaying IP information. Columns include IP, Geolocation/ASN, Last Seen, and First Seen. Details include an IP address from Falkenstein, Sachsen, Germany, associated with Hetzner Online GmbH, and dates." width="900" height="189" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-731464-137280-5.png 1418w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-731464-137280-5-786x165.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-731464-137280-5-768x161.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137292" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. The detected hijacked record for the ISP website.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The pDNS data also shows that minutes before observing the hijacked record, the nameservers were hijacked to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns1[.]csit-host[.]com</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns2[.]csit-host[.]com</span> as shown in Figure 6. Based on the attack similarity, we speculate that the same group conducted both attacks.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137294" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137294" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137294 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-733962-137280-6.png" alt="Screenshot of a data table related to name servers, including columns for Name Server, Last Seen, and First Seen. For the last entry the name server was hijacked. " width="900" height="388" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-733962-137280-6.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-733962-137280-6-786x339.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-733962-137280-6-1625x700.png 1625w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-733962-137280-6-768x331.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-733962-137280-6-1536x662.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137294" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. The change in NS record in the pDNS data.</figcaption></figure>
<p>We looked into recent hacking incidents for this IP address using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Zone-H[.]org</span>. Figure 7 shows two instances of web page defacement involving the same IP address in 2017 and 2023.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137296" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137296" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137296 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-737656-137280-7.png" alt="Screenshot of a website page indicating a security breach, titled 'Hacked By SMoker666' with a photo of Che Guevara and various technical data including IP addresses displayed on the page." width="900" height="868" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-737656-137280-7.png 1760w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-737656-137280-7-456x440.png 456w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-737656-137280-7-726x700.png 726w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-737656-137280-7-768x741.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-737656-137280-7-1536x1482.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137296" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. The screenshots taken from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Zone-H[.]org</span> show that the hijacked IP address was also involved in past incidents.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-137280-_e1jlvjmug4o"></a><strong>A Domain Name of a Hungarian Political Party Hijacked</strong></h3>
<p>The Democratic Coalition (DK), until recently the largest political opposition to the Hungarian government, owns the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dkujpest[.]hu</span>. This domain has been using IP addresses from the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">37.9.175[.]0/24</span> subnet since 2017.</p>
<p>A web hosting company in Bratislava, Slovakia called WebSupport S.R.O. manages this IP subnet. The nameservers for the domain for several years were:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Ns1.gyumolcstarhely[.]hu</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Ns2.gyumolcstarhely[.]hu</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Ns3.gyumolcstarhely[.]hu</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Ns1.webonic[.]hu, ns2.webonic[.]hu</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Ns3.webonic[.]hu</span></li>
</ul>
<p>These nameserver domains also seem to be operated by WebSupport S.R.O. After the attack, the domain operators switched the nameservers to:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Ns1.websupport[.]hu</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Ns1.websupport[.]hu</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Ns1.websupport[.]hu</span></li>
</ul>
<p>We hypothesize that WebSupport S.R.O. changed the nameservers after the attack to increase security or control. Upon reporting this to representatives for WebSupport, they replied that only administrators of the domain can change DNS records, indicating that WebSupport is not the domain administrator.</p>
<p>On Jan. 28, 2024, our model detected that <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dkujpest[.]hu</span> suddenly resolved to a new German IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">152.70.176[.]210</span>. We also found that the domain briefly resolved to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">135.148.57[.]147</span>, another German IP address.</p>
<p>These IP addresses are in a different ISP and ASN that we have never seen before for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dkujpest[.]hu</span>. Our web crawler found that the original web content shown in Figure 8 was changed to a phishing login page spoofing Microsoft shown in Figure 9. We confirmed with the maintainer of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dkujpest[.]hu</span> and its hosting provider WebSupport S.R.O. that these hijacking IP addresses and the spoofed Microsoft login page are not part of their infrastructure.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137298" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137298" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137298 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-741898-137280-8.png" alt="News website homepage featuring various articles, logos and an image of a person speaking at a podium with another individual in the background, under the headline about an ongoing conference." width="900" height="900" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-741898-137280-8.png 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-741898-137280-8-440x440.png 440w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-741898-137280-8-700x700.png 700w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-741898-137280-8-300x300.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-741898-137280-8-768x768.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137298" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. The webpage of domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dkujpest[.]h</span>u before DNS hijacking.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_137300" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137300" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137300 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-745816-137280-9.png" alt="Screenshot of faked Microsoft sign-in webpage with an email text field displayed, along with 'Next' button and links for account recovery." width="900" height="900" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-745816-137280-9.png 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-745816-137280-9-440x440.png 440w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-745816-137280-9-700x700.png 700w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-745816-137280-9-300x300.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-745816-137280-9-768x768.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137300" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. The webpage of domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dkujpest[.]hu</span> after DNS hijacking.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Two of the biggest Hungarian news portals, <a href="https://hvg.hu/itthon/20240130_unatkozo_tinedzser_hekkertamadas_DK_ujpesti" target="_blank" rel="noopener">HVG</a> and <a href="https://telex.hu/techtud/2024/01/30/dk-ujpest-honlap-weboldal-hekkertamadas-hekkeles-defacement-adatszivargas-emailcimek-elkoveto-hekker-interju" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Telex</a>, covered the hacking of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dkujpest[.]hu</span> two days after our model detected it.</p>
<h3><a id="post-137280-_wa5xw6pn52x3"></a><strong>Ongoing Illicit Gambling Campaign: A Research Center’s and a University’s Domains Hijacked</strong></h3>
<p>On the second of April 2024, we detected a new IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">139.59.255[.]10</span> from Singapore for a research center’s domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c-sharp[.]in</span>. This new IP address was suspicious because <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c-sharp[.]in</span> had been using a U.S.-based IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">208.91.198[.]24</span> since 2014.</p>
<p>Our web crawler found that DNS hijackers changed the original website hosted on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">208.91.198[.]24</span> shown in Figure 10 to an illicit gambling website hosted on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">139.59.255[.]10</span>, shown in Figure 11.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_137302" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137302" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137302 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-749237-137280-10.png" alt="Screenshot of the Centre for Sexuality and Health Research and Policy (C-SHaRP) website homepage featuring navigation tabs such as About Us, Research, Publications, Training, Partners, and Get Involved, along with various sections including recent news updates, featured research topics, journal articles, and an invitation to participate in studies." width="900" height="900" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-749237-137280-10.png 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-749237-137280-10-440x440.png 440w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-749237-137280-10-700x700.png 700w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-749237-137280-10-300x300.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-749237-137280-10-768x768.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137302" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. The webpage of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">domain c-sharp[.]in</span> hosted on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">208.91.198[.]24</span> before DNS hijacking.</figcaption></figure><figure id="attachment_137304" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137304" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137304 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-752519-137280-11.png" alt="Website homepage of Laku Toto displaying promotional graphics for online gambling, featuring a cartoon-style mouse and pig, with various elements like coins, a treasure chest, and a bold claim of a 99% win rate. The layout includes a login button and menus for game navigation." width="900" height="900" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-752519-137280-11.png 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-752519-137280-11-440x440.png 440w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-752519-137280-11-700x700.png 700w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-752519-137280-11-300x300.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-752519-137280-11-768x768.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137304" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. The webpage of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">domain c-sharp[.]in</span> hosted on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">139.59.255[.]10</span> after DNS hijacking.</figcaption></figure>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Additionally, we detected <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ccdc[.]org[.]do</span>, which also resolved to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">139.59.255[.]10</span> on June 28, indicating that this group of cybercriminals continuously look for potential domains to hijack.</p>
<p>In a similar case, we found that <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uts[.]ac[.]id</span> (a university's domain) started resolving to a Singaporean IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">159.223.92[.]200</span> on Jan. 13, 2024. However, the domain has exclusively used an Indonesian IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">103.84.194[.]81</span> since 2017.</p>
<p>We also observed that the hijacker added many new subdomains, two new nameserver domains and one mail server DNS record:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Ns5.uts.ac[.]id</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Ns6.uts.ac[.]id</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Mail.uts.ac[.]id</span></li>
</ul>
<p>We found that these new subdomains and the original nameservers resolved to the hijacker's IP address (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">159.223.92[.]20</span>) during the attack. Like in the previous case, our web crawler found that DNS hijackers changed the original website hosted on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">103.84.194[.]81</span> (Figure 12) to an illicit gambling website hosted on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">159.223.92[.]200</span> (Figure 13).</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_137306" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137306" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137306 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-756231-137280-12.png" alt="A screenshot of the homepage of Sumbawa University of Technology's website, featuring a section on a tree planting program in Kalong. The page includes a menu with options like Academics, Research, and Campus Life, and an image of a scenic green field and mountains under a cloudy sky." width="900" height="478" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-756231-137280-12.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-756231-137280-12-786x418.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-756231-137280-12-1318x700.png 1318w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-756231-137280-12-768x408.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-756231-137280-12-1536x816.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137306" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. The webpage of domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uts.ac[.]id</span> before DNS hijacking.</figcaption></figure><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> </span></span></p>
<p><figure id="attachment_137308" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137308" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137308 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-760861-137280-13.png" alt="Promotional graphic for JIMATOTO, featuring a vibrant casino theme with various game depictions including slot machines and playing cards. The top section shows welcome text and a registration button. Below are lists and graphics of game providers, and different transaction methods. Highlighted at the bottom are potential bonuses and live chat options." width="900" height="900" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-760861-137280-13.png 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-760861-137280-13-440x440.png 440w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-760861-137280-13-700x700.png 700w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-760861-137280-13-300x300.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/word-image-760861-137280-13-768x768.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137308" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. The webpage of domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uts.ac[.]id</span> after DNS hijacking.</figcaption></figure><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The two IP addresses share the same ISP and ASN. Furthermore, they use the hijacked domains to promote similar illicit gambling sites, indicating these two hijacking cases are likely part of the same campaign.</span></span></p>
<h2><a id="post-137280-_9ruwautiw4gk"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Our machine learning-based pipeline processes an average of 167 million new DNS records daily and leverages hundreds of terabytes of pDNS and geolocation data to detect DNS hijacking. Every day, our detector flags dozens of records as hijacking to protect our customers. Recently, we deployed a new version of our model that can detect DNS hijacking in our customers' traffic in around 10 minutes.</p>
<p>We observe that cybercriminals use compromised domains to host phishing content, to deface websites, or to spread illicit content. In this post, we selected examples of DNS hijacking that our automatic pipeline has found, including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>One of the largest utility companies in the U.S.</li>
<li>A large ISP</li>
<li>A major political party in Hungary</li>
<li>A university</li>
<li>A research center</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/ngfw" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a> customers receive protection from DNS hijacking via our automated classifier in the Palo Alto Networks <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> subscription service.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xpanse" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Xpanse</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xsiam" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XSIAM</a> can help customers detect and respond to potential subdomain hijacking risks by identifying susceptible CNAME DNS records on customer-attributed domains.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137280-_lrf0vb6rqcpr"></a>Acknowledgments</h2>
<p>We want to thank Reethika Ramesh, Bradley Duncan, Lysa Myers, and Arun Kumar for their invaluable input on this article.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137280-_rnmgm4gb5xrd"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<p>DNS hijacking records</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c-sharp[.]in A 139.59.255[.]10</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ccdc.org[.]do A 139.59.255[.]10</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dkujpest[.]hu A 135.148.57[.]147</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dkujpest[.]hu A 152.70.176[.]210</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mail.uts.ac[.]id A 159.223.92[.]200</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns1.uts.ac[.]id A 159.223.92[.]200</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns2.uts.ac[.]id A 159.223.92[.]200</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns3.uts.ac[.]id A 159.223.92[.]200</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns4.uts.ac[.]id A 159.223.92[.]200</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns5.uts.ac[.]id A 159.223.92[.]200</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns6.uts.ac[.]id A 159.223.92[.]200</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uts.ac[.]id A 159.223.92[.]200</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uts.ac[.]id NS ns5.uts.ac[.]id</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uts.ac[.]id NS ns6.uts.ac[.]id</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">uts.ac[.]id MAIL mail.uts.ac[.]id</span></li>
</ul>
<p>IP addresses used by attackers</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">135.148.57[.]147</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">139.59.255[.]10</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">152.70.176[.]210</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">159.223.92[.]200</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">176.9.24[.]28</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Nameservers used by attackers</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns1[.]csit-host[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ns2[.]csit-host[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
      
              </div>

              <div class="be__post-nav">
    <a class="prev" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="detect-dns-hijacking-passive-dns:article-nav:Threat Research Center"> 
        <span>Threat Research Center</span>
    </a>
            <a class="next" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/edr-bypass-extortion-attempt-thwarted/" role="link" title="TA Phone Home: EDR Evasion Testing Reveals Extortion Actor&#039;s Toolkit" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="detect-dns-hijacking-passive-dns:article-nav:TA Phone Home: EDR Evasion Testing Reveals Extortion Actor&#039;s Toolkit"> 
            <span>Next: TA Phone Home: EDR Evasion Testing Reveals Extortion Actor&#039;s Toolkit</span>
        </a>
    </div>
 
            </div>
            <div class="be__nav">
            <div class="be__nav-wrapper">

                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/01_DNS_Overview_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="A pictorial representation of using autoencoders to detect malicious DNS traffic.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="detect-dns-hijacking-passive-dns:related-resources:Autoencoder Is All You Need: Profiling and Detecting Malicious DNS Traffic:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-08-21T10:00:01+00:00">August 21, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/profiling-detecting-malicious-dns-traffic/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="detect-dns-hijacking-passive-dns:related-resources:Autoencoder Is All You Need: Profiling and Detecting Malicious DNS Traffic">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Autoencoder Is All You Need: Profiling and Detecting Malicious DNS Traffic</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/malicious-domains/" title="Malicious Domains" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="detect-dns-hijacking-passive-dns:related-resources:Autoencoder Is All You Need: Profiling and Detecting Malicious DNS Traffic:Malicious Domains">Malicious Domains</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/c2/" title="C2" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="detect-dns-hijacking-passive-dns:related-resources:Autoencoder Is All You Need: Profiling and Detecting Malicious DNS Traffic:C2">C2</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/machine-learning/" title="Machine Learning" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="detect-dns-hijacking-passive-dns:related-resources:Autoencoder Is All You Need: Profiling and Detecting Malicious DNS Traffic:Machine Learning">Machine Learning</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/profiling-detecting-malicious-dns-traffic/" title="Autoencoder Is All You Need: Profiling and Detecting Malicious DNS Traffic" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="detect-dns-hijacking-passive-dns:related-resources:Autoencoder Is All You Need: Profiling and Detecting Malicious DNS Traffic:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of ransomware activity in the first half of 2024. A digitial illustration of a lock made up of nodes glowing against a background of bokeh points." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/trend-reports/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="detect-dns-hijacking-passive-dns:related-resources:Ransomware Review: First Half of 2024:Trend Reports"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-report-white-1.svg" alt=" category icon">Trend Reports</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-08-09T10:00:03+00:00">August 9, 2024</time></span>

                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">

                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Person in a blurred motion is working on a computer with screen showing lines of code, emphasizing a dynamic and intense focus on software development or programming in a dimly lit room." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure>

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="detect-dns-hijacking-passive-dns:related-resources:DarkGate: Dancing the Samba With Alluring Excel Files:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-07-10T19:00:54+00:00">July 10, 2024</time></span>

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			                 <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:400px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			                  <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:949px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

<footer class="footer"> 
  <div class="footer-menu">
    <div class="l-container">
      <div class="footer-menu__wrapper">
        <div class="footer-menu-nav__wrapper">
                      <h3 class="footer-menu-nav__title">Products and services</h3>
                                <div class="nav-column__wrapper"> 
            <div class="nav-column">
              													<nav>
					<ul class="footer-menu-nav__list"> 
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item nav-title"> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security"   role="link" title="Network Security Platform" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Network Security Platform">Network Security Platform</a>
						</li>    
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item nav-title"> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-subscriptions"   role="link" title="CLOUD DELIVERED SECURITY SERVICES" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Network Security Platform:CLOUD DELIVERED SECURITY SERVICES">CLOUD DELIVERED SECURITY SERVICES</a>
						</li>    
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item ">

	<div class="pa language-dropdown">
			<div class="language-dropdown__wrapper"> 
			<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/globe-icon.svg" alt="Globe icon">
			<span id="selectedLanguage">EN</span>
			<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/down-arrow.svg" alt="Down arrow"><ul><li class="title">Select your language</li>
					<li class="selected" data-value="en"> 
						<a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:language-selector:en" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/detect-dns-hijacking-passive-dns/">USA (ENGLISH)</a>
					</li></ul>        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</footer>
<div class="dd-overlay">

                  <label class="is-hidden" for="volumeBar">Volume</label>

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.2' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</body>
</html>
